intros:
Kia ora! I’m Tui the deepsea blind lobster.

I’m tiny—my shell (carapace) is only about 3 centimeters long—and I scuttle slowly along the seafloor far below the waves, around 300 to 2,200 meters deep. It’s pitch‑dark there, so I don’t rely on eyes; I feel my way with long antennae.

I’m harmless and tidy, cleaning up little snacks that drift down. Scientists first found relatives of mine near Tasmania a long time ago—deep, quiet, cozy.

Hello! I’m Kwame, a deepsea blind lobster from the Atlantic side.

I like calm, chilly places on the continental slope, where I can shuffle over the bottom and mind my business. I’m small but sturdy, and most of my family has tiny or reduced eyes—perfect for the dark.

Think of me as a gentle undersea janitor: slow steps, careful feelers, and a big appetite for leftovers.

Hi there! I’m Luz the deepsea blind lobster.

My home stretches from parts of the Pacific to the Southeast Atlantic, and I keep close to the seafloor. I don’t pinch or poke—I’m a harmless little cleaner.

I was described by scientists back in the 1800s, and they still spot us in deep places today. If a camera ever sees me, I’ll wave hello with my feelers and keep on scooting.
